reviews.review_text: If you are the type who keeps working at something until you get it perfect, try this game! If you like games such as the Build-A-Lot, Farm Frenzy and Tycoon simulators, this is for you.   It's a bit tricky to wrap your head around to start with, the tutorials teach you the bare basics (there's alot to figure out yourself as you go) and I almost gave up - but it is a puzzle game for a reason! Now I have a handle on the game mechanics, it's so addictive I can't go a day without playing.   By far the trickiest part of the game after learning how to make successful drugs, is how to handle loans and income streams. You can't really do much without taking out loans (or at least this is how my gameplay works).   I've tried looking for a similar game but haven't been able to find one. I'm hoping they release a similar game before I tire of this one! Getting master on all levels is very difficult, so it should be a while :)   Just downloaded the DLC and looking forward to many many more hours of enjoyment. 10/10

I wanted this game to scratch the same itch as games like Infinifactory and Factorio, but I found the game to be a bit of planning and then a whole lot of waiting around.  The goal of maximising your profits meant that I would pause the game as I planned out each build chain, and then when I finally unpaused, all I could do is sit and watch for a long time as either my Scientists or Explorers gathered more progression for me, or I earned enough profit to pause the game and build something else.  Also the lack of a planning mode/phase meant that I would waste money after I build most of a production line, only to find out that either I miscalculated or ran out of room. If you place a conveyer it costs you $100, and if you then destroy it you only get $50 back, even if you did it right away! If perhaps the game only charged you upon unpausing the game, then perhaps you could go nuts building everything without fear of going broke due to mistakes.  I felt like the random elements in the game did not offer enough variability in how you play the game. It's just a matter of looking at the few incredients you have available via the unnecessarily clunky interface, mixing them in the same ways, and producing a product that you then proceed to forget about because it is time to move on to the next product. Then you run out of sockets and just spend the next 30 minutes watching the timer count down and your bank balance go up.  This game simply is not for me. I gave it a fair shot but found myself pushing myself to give it more, in hopes that something would change or get better.

I love puzzle games, but I'm not afraid to admit when they get to be too much for me. SpaceChem is a perennial favorite of mine that I burned out on way before the end, for example. Big Pharma shares certain similarities with SpaceChem, but with a layer of corporate management on top of the mind-bending puzzles. It's an interesting combination, and also a very exhausting one.  You get to be the CEO of a pharmaceutical company, which turns out to be a lot more interior design and number-crunching than the vlogging and buying Wu-Tang albums that I expected. Starting with a small empty room, you import ingredients through hatches in the walls, run them through a gauntlet of machines, and funnel the resulting pills, creams, and tinctures back out for a profit. Each ingredient has positive and negative effects that are activated at different concentrations, so your machines can raise, lower, and rescramble concentrations to make effective medicines.  Cramming all the necessary machines and connecting converyor belts into the space you have is your primary concern. You can research and unlock more efficient machines but you're trading space efficiency for higher running costs, which must be weighed against the profit of the drug. These values in turn fluctuate with the cost of ingredients, the market demand for that cure, and any competitor companies in that market. This is the management layer I spoke of and while you can do well enough ignoring price fluctuations, more difficult scenarios and the Master-level goals require you to retool your operation based on the market, especially once patents come into play and companies start locking each other out of producing specific cures.  This additional layer of complexity may be unwelcome to those just trying to wrap their brains about their assembly lines. Cures can be upgraded to more valuable remedies by hitting specific concentrations with specific machines. This sometimes requires catalysts mixed in with special machines, which might also require re-arranging your chemical's traits with yet another machine. All of these processes must then be crammed into limited space, and layout mistakes can be costly to undo. An efficient, profitable line is incredibly gratifying to put together, but it can be a difficult road to get there.  You'll have over three dozen scenarios to choose from, with goals ranging from make X dollars over Y years to deliver Z quantity of a specific drug. Regardless of your goals, the means will be similar, building assembly lines for simple drugs while you research the ingredients and tools to make more complex ones, and refactoring everything when you start to run out of space. New machines, upgrades, and rules may come into play in later scenarios, but never to particularly dramatic effect. It's one of those games where you really have to love the core gameplay loop because it's not going to deviate much from scenario to scenario.  The presentation is perfect for a puzzle game, with clear, colorful, cartoony shapes and pleasing animations for all your machines. I want to give special recognition to the sound effects, which reach Blizzard-levels of polish for how perfect and gratifying they are to hear. Machines make delightful buzzes and clanks, belts whirr along happily, and even the buttons have rich bleeps and bloops to them. It's an excellent concept assembled and presented as well as anyone could expect, so the only question is how long you'll care to stick with it. There's not a lot of variety to building lines or running your company, but if you want to build Rube Goldbergian coveyors and tax your brain in turning a profit, you'll find no end of content to keep you happy.

As a fan of games like Spacechem, the old Mysts and 7th Guest, TIS-100 even and pretty much any other that requires heavy thinking, I really don't get why there are 'so many' (22% as of now) bad reviews about this game.  Big Pharma is not as hard on your brain as some of these games I mentioned above but it does require a fair amount of thought and planning, specially at the begining when you're not used to it, and the hardest levels are also pretty challenging.  Put simply (if you're not in the mood for reading everything): the game is good, it keeps you entertained and focused for plenty of time.  People writing bad reviews mostly claim that:  1 - The game gets repetitive/boring - I disagree. Well, ok, every game gets repetitive - even life itself does - and Big Pharma is no exception. Still, you always get a rewarding sense of accomplishment when you see your production lines running efficiently, your drugs selling more than your competitors (and for a higher price) and when you get good trial reviews because you're a good man and ran the extra mile to make them patient-friendly. Also, every level has a different objective, and you can get a standard, expert or master 'score' on each, depending on how fast (usually) you achieved your objective, and that keeps you on your toe every time, avoiding any mistakes to get your 'master' rank in every level. You do, indeed, start every single level with the same formula (slight variations, but the same routine), but I find the game is still fun after 20+ hours playing it, mainly because achieving the master rank in the toughest levels is a good challenge.  2 - The 'managing aspect' isn't a big part of the game - Again, I disagree. You absolutely need the money aspect, and it fits the game perfectly in my opinion. You must keep your drugs (and their sales rating, if you have the DLC, which I recommend) profitable, your income on the green, to be able to keep going. You must beat your competitors (and fast) or they'll end up showering you with patents and taking a huge share of the market, diminishing your sales. You gotta be careful with the loans you get so their interest don't end up eating all of of your profits, and also balance how many explorers/scientists you have - and what they are currently working on - to keep enough cash flowing in and your company, again, ahead of the competition. In my opinion, the management aspect works perfectly with the puzzle/logistic facet of Big Pharma. It's a double-fun experience, specially if you're the type of person who enjoys both things.  I think that covers most of the 'thumbs down' this game has received.  ***  About the DLC:  If you liked the base game, you'll like the DLC. It adds some neat new features (check the DLC's steam page for specifics.)  ***  On a serious note / Something special about this game:  There's a very interesting and particular side to Big Pharma: it opens your eyes for how the REAL 'Big Pharma Industry' works, or at the very least it makes you think about it.  In this game, you can leave side-effects on drugs on purpose (and regulate their, as well as the cure's, strenght as you will) to keep demand for some of your other drugs (those that treat such side effects) up high. You can patent your drugs to get a temporary monopoly of a market's share and raise your prices up to the sky. With the DLC, you can run trials on your drugs and deliberately disqualify the bad results to trick the consumers and raise your sales. You... see where I'm going with this.  After playing this game, one must wonder: 'Dude... this can totally be done for real. Maybe real companies do this kind of stuff.' Then you keep thinking about it and... 'Why wouldn't they? Well... maybe they have principles, and goodness in their heart. Maybe they want to help people.' But wait... we're talking about some of the (if not THE) richest people in the world, people you never heard about, people whose names no one knows. People who torture lab animals on a daily basis, who tested prototype-drugs on jew prisoners during Hitler's Reich. People who profit from the suffering of the sick and weakened, and make a living extorting the dying. People who steal an old guy's economies dry under false promises of an unlikely cure (**Google 'cancer' here**).  Finally, you'll find yourself concluding: 'Man... screw polititians, mexican cartels, weapon dealers and african warlords. Big Pharma - that's the real nemesis of mankind.'  I just read that Johnson & Johnson was just condemned to pay and indemnification of 55 million dolars to a woman because one of their talc powders gave her cancer. The doctors had to remove her ovary, and it was literally lined with talc. And that's a second (at least) for them because, months ago, they had to pay 72 million to another woman for the same reason.  If this example and reason alone aren't enough for you, Google 'Big Pharma' or any company's specific name (Johnson & Jhonson, Pfizer, etc.) and read for yourself.  What I know is I'm never taking any medicine again unless it's strictly necessary (AKA I'm in heavy, constant pain). If you keep thinking about all this stuff, it's easy to see how far these companies can/could/do go to take your money (like an infinite chain of side-effects and their temporary-with-more-side-effects treatments). Seriously, we are on the 'genetic mapping age', how hard can it be for trillionaires (the Big Pharma industry generates a trillion dolars per year) to cut off side effects and balance a drug's components if they want to? Damn, even I can do it, according to Big Pharma (the game).  ***  Conclusion:  Big Pharma is a very nice game. It gives you a sense of reward every time you score a 'master' on the tough levels and that's the raw thing every game aims for. If you like puzzle/management games, I'd say this one should keep the average guy entertained for 30-40 hours, maybe more (it took me 70 hours just to get 'Master' on all the levels in 'Advanced' and beyond). That's good value for your money, and this is the kind of game that you start playing at 6pm, play for one or two hours straight, quit, and realizes it's already 11pm.  If you're concerned about the negative reviews (I always and seriously take them into account myself), maybe you can wait for a sale, but I really don't think you'll regret your purchase at full price, as long as you understand what the game is like (the screenshots alone can give you a fair idea) and feel you are going to enjoy it - the game's execution itself is great, that is not going to disappoint you.  EDIT: btw, I never got a single bug or crash whatsoever.  EDIT 2: ok, now the game has crashed once, after 45 hours or so.  EDIT 3: I just found out that this game was made by ONE dude, alone. That always baffles me (Terraria was also made by a single guy, if I'm not mistaken). I, myself, can barely get dressed on my own, so... congratulations Tim, amazing job.

Big Pharma is a surprisingly entertaining little game with some great puzzle elements and an enjoyable biz sim. Here are my pros and cons.  Pros: 1. Enjoyable puzzle mechanic that makes creating new drugs addictive. 2. Impressivle large list of items to research and drugs to create. 3. Enojoyable and simple UI that is very sleek and well designed Cons 1. Game sondtrack isnt varied and it can get annoying listening to the same couple of tunes over and over 2. The game lacks alot of options and stats that you would really wanna see and would vastly help you get more info about your income and costs, but the new DLC really takes great strides to improve this area so I would highly recommend getting the DLC. 3. While I personally think the price is acceptable I defiantely feel that for pure amount of content it is slightly above where it shold be listed, 15 or 20 sound more reasonable. (Get it on sale and it will be well worth it.)  In general the game is awesome and if you're any fan of company simulations or medical sims youll love this game. The team seems so far to be doing a great job, they are consistantly updating the game and using to dlc to add some real needed mechanics that make the game far more enjoyable and give it more depth. Im excited to see what DLC they'll be offering next. The game has so much potential for even greater growth with dlc and im excited to see where it leads.

First off: I own this game from their website before the steam release, so my playtime is higher than the 0.4 hours it claims right now.  TLDR: Even though I like many aspects of the game, I can not recommend it at its price as it will not keep you entertained for very long.  Do I somewhat like the game? Yes. Would I recommend it? Not really, especially not for 23 Euros.  I love the setting, I feel there should be way more disease/medical-related games and I do enjoy the graphics, by which I mean I don't mind the simplicity. I like the making of new drugs, the setting up of belts/arrangements, the tight budget, the slight humour, the ideas like exploration and the reasearch tree.  So why wouldn't I recommend it? Because it gets boring, and it does so rather quick. The reason for this is, that its repetetive. Gamesessions usually are done in 1-3 Hours depending on difficulty and consist of you researching new techs and producing new medications with increased difficulty in the setup of your conveyer-belts.  The Problem is that its the same each mission. And the Drugs/Ingredients are completly interchangeable. Unless youre a 'Letsplayer' you wont care for the name of the made-up Drugs/Ingredients within seconds but they will just be stats like 'increase/decrease concentration by 3' so thats all you do.  You find the easiest way to reach that wanted concentration. And theres only (when fully researched) like 3 ways of increasing decreasing, meaning +/- 1 ; +/-3 ; half/double. So thats not hard! In fact nothing is really 'hard' in this game. Theres no need to make difficult choices, as you will most likely produce every medice you can as far as research and exploration go, since every 'tick' gives money, theres also no need to think about if you should keep the medicine going - if it ticks in money, keep it, if it loses money, replace it.  The result is a very easy game and the 'challange' comes from increasingly hard scenarios. But this doesn't mean anything interesting like 'do this-and-that with 3 rooms' or so, no, while there are ~5 different types on missions they all play the same, as you just need to make more of the best kind of medicine, cure a number of people, make some money or something along those lines, so they all mean you build up your, lets say 'empire' and then at some point you win. And weather your task is to make 5-super-medicines or to make X Million $ doesnt matter as you do the very same thing. The Difficulty of the Game (which does go quite high in the late game) only comes from increasingly narrow timelimits, so the medium and hard difficulty is identical, except in one you need to make (lets say, not sure about the real number right now as it doesnt matter) 5 Milion in 10 years and on hard its 10 Million in 5 Years.  So after 10 hours lets say you will start more than your 10th game (the easy games go by rather fast) and you will do the very same thing the 10th time in a row, still not caring. And since setting up the conveyer belt-systems is the only real aspect, and you do that about once every 5 minutes, you will have done that about 120 times. And then its just routine, theres no fun to be had (there hasn't been in quite a while) and all you do is click your new belt, wait for money to pour in, click your new belt a.s.o.

In   Big Pharma  , you take the role of a CEO of a pharmaceutical company, and you have to take your fledgling company from minor painkiller pusher to mega-corporate cancer killer.  At the start of the game, you are dumped into an empty factory lot where you will be able to start building production machines and start manufacturing some cures. Each segment of the factory will have an input point where you can choose to pull through certain ingredients which may or may not have positive attributes. Running these ingredients through a careful setup of specific machines will either emphasise or dissipate the base positive or negative effects of your ingredients. Once youâ€™re happy with the result, throw what you have into a pill machine and pipe it out through one of your output points where it will be given a name and shipped off into the world to be sold.   You can also put scientists hard at work to research some brand new machines and ingredients, or simply improve existing ones. This is a nice way to improve the quality of your production lines and keep a consistent, stable way of producing reliable cures and boost profits the legitimate way.  The   Marketing and Malpractice   DLC helps to give you more control on the money side of things, and instead of just selling a cure for a set price throughout you can hike the cost of a drug when you know the demand is high and people are in desperate need of it; something as simple as a paracetamol may be in high demand after a tragedy somewhere in the world, and you can use it as an opportunity to charge a fortune for it. You can also undercut a competitor to gain your own company more money at the expense of theirs, adding new ways to play   Big Pharma   and causing you to be savvy off the production floor as well.    Big Pharma   does feel unique, as itâ€™s rare to get an economic/sim game that was built from the design level up to be a morality play on human greed. People who enjoy business sims, and want to engage with something that requires planning without overzealous micromangement may find   Big Pharma   to be the cure.   THE GOOD  - Unique morality play in a sim game - Addictive gameplay  - Adds a new personal approach to playing - Perks system   THE BAD  - Feels somewhat barren - Suffers from repetitive gameplay - Once youâ€™ve played around with the features it loses appeal  DISASTER | BAD | MEDIOCRE | OKAY |   GOOD   | GREAT | AMAZING | MASTERPIECE

Good: o Interesting and unique concept o Random ingredients o You can customize the medicine you produce allowing making multiple choices  Bad: o Not much interaction between you and your competitors o Gets really repetitive after 2 games o Save often, on average this game crashes 10-15x per game session. I spent most of my time re-doing something (hence the repetitive-ness)  Word to developer: o Make it stable, if you cant, put in auto-save every 5 mins or so, that will ensure players wont lose everything they have works on

I don't know how you'd pin this, so let's just call it what it is: stressfully fun  Its got something of a puzzle in the mix, where you gotta create drugs with certain effects, but those effects can only be made known with certain machines, and its really easy to mix up what machine does which.  Its graphically what you'd expect, music is good, tutorial is a bit hamfisted but it gets the job done. I do wish the machines were'nt so odd to drop onto the lab floor. LIke, some of them are 's' shaped, where the input is on the opposite side of the output, and its also sideways, so you gotta spend more time working around an oddly shaped machine in order to run it through the exact same oddly-shaped machine, and its never quite fun to do so.  However, seeing everything come together makes all that effort worth it to great effect. A great game to get on sale, and when you're bored.  8/10

Big Pharma is an exquisite puzzle game and management sim. I haven't had this much fun since playing Sim Hospital. Even without mod support (it has mod support!) the game provides hours and hours of mind-bending, head-scratching fun.

I wish there was a way to write a neutral, as I could go either way on this game.  Obviously, I have played a lot of hours, but as another reviewer mentioned, you get to the point of wanting to complete all the missions/scenarios instead of playing for fun.  Figuring out how the machines work, strategies for making money, etc are fun at first. What happens is it takes some time to get machines unlocked, etc. while playing in missions, so you find yourself doing essentially the same strategy for every scenario up to the point of fulfilling the mission objectives. For example, several missions are 'earn xxx profit in xxx time' - well that's easy enough once you have done it for $1,000,000 you can do it for $10,000,000. There are missions like 'cure xxx xxx times' or 'supply xxx drugs', again, once you do those once, it's fairly easy to repeat. The AI players are pretty much a non-threat.  I believe there's a good 20 hours of playtime in the game. After that, it starts to become repetitive.  My advise: Buy it on sale. $15 or under would be OK.  To the devs: Game is good but too expensive for what it is - I wish the missions were more varied. I wish you could really ramp up the difficulty and the AI was an actual competitior. For example, being able to bankrupt the AI or having the AI complete the same mission objectives you are would be good.
Combining puzzles with basic tycoon gameplay, I would describe Big Pharma as a shrunk down, sped up version of Rollercoaster Tycoon. Great aesthetics and excellent learning curve, to boot.

One of the best 'factory' games I've played. Definitely a fun game that's got a lot of long-term playability (currently 50+ hours played). I had a bit of trouble at first figuring out how to do transmutations or whatever it is called to create more complex meds, but overall I found the game quite enjoyable, easy to learn, and a good mix of managing costs, productions and logistics.   I have not played the expansion (and currently do not plan to, because price micromanagement doesn't see as fun), but the base game provides plenty enjoyment for me.

Initially, I liked the game. But as I replayed, I found it pretty boring to always research ingredients and technology in the same order. Music and graphics are poor for today's games, but I would have easily forgiven based on a cheaper price if it had great game play. I just didn't think this really had it. Also, I found myself SO frustrated on one of the Intermediate scenarios that I basically quit the game: the scenario called for making XX of a highly complex drug and I felt like there was a glitch that wasn't allowing my drug to make its final transformation. That did it for me.

Big Pharma is a well made and well presented puzzle game, themed around making drugs. As such it works well, and the complexity added to building a production line by deciding how you want to balance benefits, side effects and cost/profit adds enough spice to play the game.  I've read a few reviews which complain that the game is not a pharma business sim. It doesn't claim to be one, so it seems a bit odd that it being criticised for that. Take it for what it is, a good puzzle game with a solid theme.
I don't really know how to explain this, there's not very much wrong with the gam...........except it's just boring. It looks great and works great but it's just not enough for me.
When you have to make the decision to export a poor quality hypertension pill in order to ensure your cure for HIV is symptom free - the struggle is real.

Not as much fun as you might expect a game about running a pharmaceutical company to be.  If you enjoy optimizing processes, you might really enjoy this game. 'Part business sim, part logistics puzzle' is fair, although the business sim is fairly shallow. It is interesting to work out how to get from chemicals A, B, and C to result Z, but it never really builds to anything greater.

Got lost in this one. The luck involved is frustrating sometimes, but when things work it's really exciting. In most sims, once you set up your engine it becomes too easy, this one keeps you on your toes. As the market becomes saturated your drugs lose value and you need to invest capital to stay current.   The loan system truly makes this game. Shopping terms to keep your business growing, yet in the green is great.   Anyone who likes business simulators should grab this one, worth every penny.
Less of a economic simulation, rather a puzzle game reminisent of 90's games. Altogether, best WE WUZ PFIZER N SHIEET simulator.

This is a clever little simulation game. The challenge comes in two forms. The first is a business management simulation, not unlike Theme Hospital or similar games. The second part of the game is a spacial puzzle. It starts out simply enough. Very simple production lines bring ingredients in and pump packaged drugs out with a few steps along the way to prepare the formula. As you progress in the game you will unlock many new ingredients and cures and technology used to prepare them.  Initially, the game only offers you selections that are available at the current level. As such, the game appears quite basic on the surface for the first dozen or so scenarios. As you progress further in to the game, however, you unlock a great deal of new research projects and technology.  Many of the negative reviews I am seeing for the game (not all, but many) are suggesting the game is very basic and has a short lifespan. These same reviews were mostly written by players who had between 2 and 6 hours of play time recorded. I suspect most of these players didn't even play long enough to see how much added complexity there is when you unlock patents and stage 4 cures, etc.  Highly recommended to programmers or anyone who enjoys optimizing engines. The production line component of the is reminiscent of SpaceChem.

If youre into managment games you will most likely love this game if you are prepared to invest in learning the game. Its not hard to learn but some of the mechanics and UI's are unusual.   The game design is quite brilliant I must say.
This game turned to be very fun to play. I like the interface, the graphics and the music.  Overall, very well done for a single man job!

I actually really like the game, but the tutorials are complete garbage. It took me a lot of exterior sources and arround 2 hours to be able to understand how to create more complex drugs like an AIDS-Cure. A game developer shouldn't have to rely on third parties in order to get people to understand their game

I wish I had bought Factorio instead of this! ... I bought both in the end. You will be hugely disappointed with this if you've played Factorio.  Good: -Idea is great! Everyone can relate to drugs and pharmacies at least on some level. You will realise that curing is not profitable, treating is. -Graphics look very pretty! -What has been implemented, has been implemented quite well.  Bad: -Very shallow in depth and repetitive. There isn't that much to do. Pretty much all incredients are treated in the same way each time, through the same machines. Only slight variations and you will end up with pretty much the same machines each time. It is a VERY linear game. -Space is very limited, so you cannot build exactly what you want. So building becomes more like a puzzle of space rather than just puzzle of machinery complexity. -'Artificial' AI enemy. You cannot see their factory and their numbers are taken out of a 'table' rather than from an actual situation.  Reason for not recommending: it is just not worth the premium price tag. It is definitely not worth Â£18.99. It is more like a Â£4.99 game, even that is pushing it.
Made erectile dysfunction drug. Made it into a cream. Named it Erection Rectifier.  10/10 Would cream up the limp noodles again.

The game has somewhat of a steep learning curve, it sure is worth the money! Love the game.  My hours are a little off, as I played the game quite some hours outside of steam.   If you consider the game, buy it!

Oh wow - this game is amazing! It is one of the best games I've played for long while. Easy to start with, but still provides proper challenge to make your cures perfect. Highly recommended if you like to optimise, solve puzzles and make your company shine.

Its a management sim, but its also a game about rudimentary programing skills. As you add logical operands (in the form of physical machinery) to modify your desired chemical, you must deal with the physical limitations of your warehouse, and attempt to maximize profit and space by using your resources effectively (much like code optimisation)  Its a great fusion of 2 genres, and the programming aspect makes it much deeper than traditional sim games where you research a tech, and instantly recieve all its benefits. No, to succeed here, you much balance your business skills with your ability to design optimised production lines.  Challenging, replayable, and unique. Definately reccomend!

I play managing games since I was a little kid, so after I saw a recommendation of this game in a magazine I got excited. I waited for a major sale and bought it. I got   highly   disappointed with the game - it's unfunny and offers poor explanations of the game's functions. I also expected the game would teach how the actual pharmaceutical business and medicine-making proccess works, but it doesn't.  5/10

Very polished game, continuously challenges you to optimize products further. The end game is complex enough to allow you to solve the layout & efficiency puzzles in multiple ways, but still comprehensible enough to play while tired or not completely sober.  The game feels pretty complete, haven't found any obvious bugs. But despite randomization of factory layout & ingredient effects, it still lacks a bit in replay value in my opinion. Certainly gives you a few days worth of puzzle/simulation/micromanagement fun. It seems that there is no new content planned though, which is a shame.  Might not be worth â‚¬20, but I'd certainly recommend to pick it up during a sale.

Very fun business-themed puzzle game with one caveat: Much of the game is randomly generated, so the difficulty will vary widely (you might start off with compounds that can easily be turned into the cure you need, or you might have to first do expensive research to unlock exploration to then send expensive explorers to find the drug in question).   As such, the different levels of challenge (normal/expert/master -e.g. you might have to achieve annual profits of 200k/500k/1000k) are pretty meaningless.

Certainly gives you a few days worth of puzzle/simulation/micromanagement fun. It seems that there is no new content planned though, which is a shame.  Might not be worth â‚¬20, but I'd certainly recommend to pick it up during a sale.

I spent twenty minutes trying to place two mixers so I could have full efficiency, but no matter how I did it the conveyors would cross, so it wouldn't work out. Someone needs to make it so you can move the outputs as a research option (Assuming that's not in the larger tech tree).  The game is quite enjoyable. I got it on sale for $20, and it's worth every cent.
Have you ever picked up a book and couldn't put it down?, This game is exactly like that. Intoxicatingly infuriatingly addictive.

This game has been a surprise hit with me! I don't normally play games like this but I decided to take the plunge and buy it anyway, and boy o' boy I was happy I did. The game puts you in a senario where you have 1 (or more) objectives to achieve. These objectives could be anything from earning money, curing cancer/ another disease or unlocking everything and making a massive monoply of drug production. I mean you can cure CANCER. BLOODY CANCER!!!!   But on a serious note this game has a medium ammount of content to offer with a high replay value. You have a total of 6 catagories of gameplay to choose from (1 of them being the tutorial levels) and under each of these catagories or dificulties there are different challenges for you to compleat. There is rival companies in the game which take market from you, make drugs and provide a gameplay challange.   There is also a free build mode with is basicall the game with god mode with infinate money, no competetors and everything unlocked. perfect for someone who just wants to make a bunch of drugs! but there is also a custome game mode where you can tune the game to your liking with options such as number of competetors, number of ingrediants, reaserch, buildings, cures, sideaffects and on and on.  The game focuses on making a production line where you pass ingrediants between machines to make the cure/ temp-cure to your disease/virus. This game os amazing for anyone intrested in recording for youtube.  Overall I highly recogmend this game to anyone intrested in a tycoon management game.

A rather okay game. An interesting idea and a complex idea. The good: it has some real science behind it, though obviously not even near 100% correct. But for the point of the game, you can ignore it. The challenges are in fact challenges. It's not an easy game. You'll have to plan a bit. I enjoyed parts of it but you can't play too long or you'll burn out. I wish I could better explain it.  Good: >You'll have fun many times >It's not easy, it's a challenge so you'll be entertained >Good music >Careful planning is rewarded >Addictive   Bad: >The beginning of each challenge is near identical as you have to restart learning the same techniques; but the parts that change are the ingredients. Based on luck. If lucky, it's easy. If not, prepare your â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥. >Some things seem utterly random , such as which side effect is on each ingredient >Some effects contradict themselves >You will be in debt a lot. No idea how people hit the 600$ daily when I can do at best 200$ when being careful (this is on EASY by the way). I constantly was close to meeting an objective, just waiting for a new loan >Competition nearly never does anything BUT when they do, they do in fact screw you over >Something is off with the economics. I have a superior product (cure and sales rating), no side effects and it ISN'T dominating the market... when the only other one is a weaker, side effect ridden competition drug. How???  Neutral: >There's a learning curve so take time to learn.  >The tutorials aren't too easy to follow, so pay attention  That's about it. It's a game that you play a challenge and once done, you take a break. Come back the next day.  Advice: Beat the tutorial. Free build is nice to test out things (a good idea, especially about combining ingredients), but is utterly boring to play in. Custom build might be better if you want to practice techniques for challenges. It gives you the ability to learn how to properly research, search for ingredients, deal with money, etc, WITHOUT being restricted.  So again: Free build if you wanna quickly try out how to combine things or how equipment works. But use custom build to practice for challenges. The challenges can be very hard and very easy. The game is rough but fun, but very exhausting. It's not the greatest but it does the job. It could learn from other games like Rollercoaster tycoon.

This is a puzzle/logistics game that dives into the economy/politics side of drug companies. There are various challenges to complete, with different tiers of success, ensuring you will come back to previous challenges with more experience and a better outcome. Some examples of challenges include, deliver 200 units of hair loss product (requiring desert research and follow-up exploration and an end-game atomic sequencer) before a set amount of time, produce 6 products with a B+ rating (you can make a few extra bucks if you don't process out side-effects, but this challenge requires you to find profitable and sustainable drugs without using questionable business practices), and make as much money as possible using patents, putting out as much product with as little work as possible, and undercutting the AI businesses as much as possible!  This game's business side is a little light, but is expanded on in the very affordable DLC that add new layers to the game. I would recommend getting the DLC, but only after you try the base game. It isn't everyone's cup of tea, but it sure is mine!
